page.title: 15Fenland Drainage
page.content: The fens used to be a series of very shallow lakes, rivers wandered down to the sea. Whittlesey was a clay island joined by causeways to other islands. Whittlesey mere was the biggest lake in southern England and was over most of the survey area. The romans attempted to drain some of the higher ground to the north of Whittlesey. They straightened some of the river Nene. Then king Offa built a dyke to cross south of Whittlesey to Ramsey. This is Kings Dyke. Mortons leam was built by Bishop Morton. Then in the 17th and 18th centuries dutch engineers came and set up the system of dykes and drains you see today. The water is pumped into rivers and then pumped into the sea by electric pumps. The peat has shrunk as it dried out and is now much lower than the river level you can see this at Holme fen.
